0.00.text:
Our next round is called
This Is My...

2.06.text: where we bring on a mystery guest

3.65.text:
who has a close connection
to one of our panellists.

6.46.text:
This week, each of Lee's team
will claim it's them

9.03.text:
that has the genuine
connection to the guest

11.10.text:
and it's up to David's team
to spot who's telling the truth.

13.87.text:
So please welcome
this week's special guest -

28.73.text: She once booked me a stripper

31.22.text:
and it went so badly that
I spent the rest of the night

36.81.text: June, how do you know Marie?

39.35.text: Well, I call her Mar-ee, you see,

41.92.text:
because Marie is going
to play the young Dot

47.23.text:
called Dot Cotton -
The Motorbike Years.

57.22.text:
And finally, Lee - what's your
relationship with Marie?

61.65.text:
She once asked me to
pop into her house

64.98.text: to get rid of a spider.

66.69.text:
Ten minutes later,
she asked me to leave,

69.30.text: because I was making matters worse.

72.27.text: All right, there you have it.

80.00.text: So, Lee - how do you know her?

82.85.text:
What, she's your
next door neighbour?

84.54.text:
Well she's my next door
neighbour's, um...nanny.

88.67.text:
Not grandmother, obviously.
That would be crazy.

94.57.text: The spider was... Including the legs?

98.87.text:
The spider was, I would say,
about that big, with legs.

102.48.text:
Well, did she come round
and knock on the door, or...

104.93.text:
How did she alert you
to the crisis?

107.90.text:
She, er... She came round
and knocked on the door.

111.15.text:
What, leaving the children
and the spider unattended?

115.44.text: Yes. And what were you doing?

117.57.text:
I was at home just watching
television, you know?

119.70.text:
Just like you do, watching
a bit of... So what time...

121.94.text:
Bit of EastEnders, as it goes.
Well. What time of day was this?

131.82.text:
So it was in the evening and, erm,
Marie knocks at the door...

135.19.text:
LEE KNOCKS DESK
..you go and answer the door...

144.86.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "Lee, you must
come very quickly."

153.29.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "There is a spider in
my house, I am very frightened."

160.88.text: So I said, "I'm not, you know,

163.77.text:
"I'm sort of watching Dot Cotton,
my favourite, you know?"

166.94.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "I don't know this
character, I've only just arrived.

169.91.text:
"Last time I was here,
it was Dirty Den."

172.32.text:
No, so we just made light
conversation about, I just said...

174.89.text:
Yeah, you made light conversation
despite her distress,

177.38.text:
despite the fact that she's leaving
unattended children in a house

180.31.text:
with an arachnid
she finds terrifying. Yeah.

182.99.text: And so you go in the house... Yeah.

194.76.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "It's in the
back room, in the back room."

197.24.text: Bathroom? It's in the back room?

198.85.text:
No, that's what I said, I said,
"No, it's bathroom," and she went,

203.06.text:
And then she went upstairs to the
bathroom... Yep. ..and she said,

209.04.text: There was a little corner cabinet.

210.85.text:
She goes, "It's under there,
it's under there", so I said,

213.66.text:
"Stand back," but I'm actually
a bit frightened of spiders.

216.23.text:
So I was trying to play it cool,
like I'll sort it out,

218.64.text:
but was terrified
of what I might see.

221.01.text: So I asked if she had any, er...

223.98.text:
like, brooms and stuff
and she passed me the broom.

226.83.text:
So I get the stick and
I try and move the thing

229.39.text: and as I'm moving the thing,

231.24.text:
the vase that was on top
fell over and smashed.

234.53.text:
Now, that was just the start
of my problems. Oh, God.

238.18.text:
Put it this way, have you ever
seen that episode of Mr Bean

240.71.text: where he tries to catch a spider?

242.68.text: No. Good, I'll use that then. So...

251.59.text: No. So I... So the vase smashes.

253.92.text:
Now... Now the child comes in,
sees me... Oh, oh.

257.01.text:
I panicked, saw the broken vase,
saw the child with no shoes on

260.62.text:
and just sort of went,
"Whoa, whoa, get out!", like that -

269.01.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "Oh! Why do you
make me cry so?" Hang on...

275.95.text:
No, no, that's what I said.
I said, he...

279.29.text:
Let me finish. I said,
"Are they French children?"

283.02.text:
FRENCH ACCENT: "No, but you know,
the parents are never here,

288.24.text:
It's unbelievable - three years
old, never been to France,

300.40.text: She shepherds them out, like that.

301.92.text:
So I got a bit more brave and I went
over to the thing, like that now

305.18.text:
and I just go for it,
I just pull it like that.

307.22.text:
The whole thing goes over,
the drawer comes out

309.75.text:
and things spill all over
from the top drawer

312.76.text:
and there's some awkward things
in the top drawer,

316.05.text:
because I am in the bathroom
that Marie uses,

321.75.text:
I'm not going to go into detail.
What sort of awkward things?

324.32.text:
I don't want to embarrass her, but...
A Lee Mack video?

335.00.text:
And did you at any point
actually see the spider?

337.69.text:
Well, that's the funny thing.
No, I didn't.

339.89.text: But you know what size it was?

341.94.text: Yes. I did. Because she told me.

346.48.text:
You described the size
quite specifically.

349.01.text: Because I listen to women, Rob!

350.61.text:
That's the difference
between me and you.

352.50.text: That's why they go out with me,

353.82.text:
because I listen to
what they have to say.

355.59.text:
I don't always go, "Did you see me
in Gavin and Stacey?"

358.24.text:
No, I'm interested
in their lives, Rob -

360.53.text: in their lives and their fears!

378.95.text:
Well, I'm pretty sure that Lee
doesn't listen to women, so...

385.05.text:
Um, what Lee's saying
is obviously, er...

389.95.text: It's just not true, is it? No.

395.08.text:
No. Aisling's absolutely
sold me on this.

397.93.text:
I can see you struggling with that
banana, it's...unquestionably...

405.96.text:
There's something about her
that's Irish.

408.01.text:
OK, we think it's...
You're going to say...?

410.06.text:
It's the stripper story.
You think it's Aisling? OK. Marie -

413.39.text:
would you please reveal
your true identity?

430.65.text:
I booked a stripper
for Aisling's birthday!

438.59.text:
Do you know what? Genuinely,
for a moment then, I thought,

445.98.text:
No, I just really wanted
that story to be true.
